comment_text: Great interview, but, come on - manned missions. Manned missions. "Crewed" is so unnatural and absurd. How are we supposed to expand the horizons of humanity when we're so limited that we get offended by "gendered terms"? If you can't handle the word "man," then you don't have the right stuff. I.e., it's babyish. Not tough, certainly not bold.
Tim, thank you sooo much for helping to make spaceflight fascinating! You have the best interviews and educational videos!

While starship is gliding in after re-entry couldn't you have ejection seats to save the crew if there is a major malfunction? Or at least for testing flights. Correct me if I'm wrong but it should be under mach before firing landing burn.

With my understanding of space suits the only way to reduce or eliminate the pre breath protocols is to use a much higher suit pressure which impacts mobility of the suit. The solution I suggest is a high pressure suit with sophisticated  power assist for walking, finger and hand dexterity and so on, and have the control of the suit synchronised with the users body via a Nuralink implant. Easier said than done of course.

I grew up following the Mercury, Gemini, and Apollo program. I’m pretty confident I’ll be around to watch the next human landing on the moon. I hope I will live long enough to see humans land on Mars.

Very exciting indeed! We get multiple Falcon Heavy launches this year and soon a Super Heavy/Starship launch!
They are really pushing the parallels to Gemini and several of you are following through with where that leads us. Mercury Redstone was sub orbital and then orbital. I think it was Glen that did 7 orbits, and Carpenter did 31? Gemini orbited, experiments with EVA and ship rendezvous, then docking. Recall that Armstrong docked with Agena to prep for the Apollo dock with a lunar lander.
I imagine Polaris 1, gets EVA and lots of experiments in, the Polaris 2 gets docking and paired navigation like Gemini did for Dragon and Starship. Need practice for HLS docking and tanker docking/fueling. Polaris 3, launch and land of Starship, with more docking of Starship tanker to Starship human rated in orbit to practice for moon and Mars trips. Dear Moon takes them around Moon for repeat of Apollo early flights, includes docking with tankers, possibly with Dragon to further practice for Artemis and lunar landing. Along the way, they may send an unmanned lander all the way to the Moon with emergency resources for Artemis. I even foresee an unmanned mission going all the way to Mars. Either round trip or attempting landing and return.

Thanks for the great interview. If there is anything I would like to find out more about it would be the space suit design. Will these be moderately improved designs similar to what has been used in the past by one of the space agencies? There was a comment about reducing issues with preparing for decompression. Current protocols require reducing pressure over a 24 hour period to 20% of standard pressure and going on pure oxygen. One method of reducing decompression time is to use counter pressure suit technology that was being developed by Dava Newman.
Any chance you could look into if SpaceX is planning to test this technology?

Anil Menon (spaceX med director) has been picked by NASA for astronaut training for the Lunar missions, and his wife Anna is heading to orbit on Polaris Dawn in around a year, with Jared's good buddy Scott Poteet and also Sarah Gillis, trainer-in-chief from SpaceX. I love the parallels to the gemini missions. SpaceX has got to the point now where they've hit the ceiling of what standard commercial aerospace does (cargo, satellites). Now comes the testing and pushing the boundaries in ways that historically only governments have done. Testing a new EVA suit, proving communications networks. I wouldn't be surprised if Polaris 2 was a Crew Dragon docking with a Starship. All culminating in Polaris 3 with a manned mission aboard the modern successor to the Saturn V. All the proof of concept work will be done in these missions so they can proceed with Dear Moon,  the HLS for NASA, and eventually Mars missions. It's been a tough few years, but stories like these make the future look bright.
I sure hope someone is filming this stuff in IMAX for future epic documentaries to stamp this stuff in history.

THIS is what we need. Sure, we need companies to compete head-on with SpaceX, but we also need companies to kind-of-compete with them, meaning fill in the gaps of what SpaceX is doing, which ends up being a collaboration-competition sort of relationship. For instance, SpaceX wouldn't have started Starlink had there been a company willing to do it themselves and buy all those launches from them. If there are people willing to come in, invest, and try to use SpaceX's capabilities, SpaceX won't try to open more fronts than it already has, but rather accept them willingly. Privately-funded space exploration is going to be AWESOME.

It's a nice dream, and we may get a man on Mars, but I don't want to burst your bubble, we will not colonize Mars. Not to mention, we don't even have the technology to put a man on Mars yet. And to think that we could one day actually become multi-planetary people is an impossibility. Not because of technology, but the human body has limits that technology cannot overcome.
You all might want to read the book of Revelation; God is going to remake the Heavens and the Earth to last for eternity. Our Sun will no longer be needed, God's glory will light the new Earth. The eco system that God created for us to live on Earth cannot be recreated to allow us to live indefinitely on another planet. With this said, i still love our space program, it has many benefits for our daily lives.

I'm a little amazed at the confidence in the speed of Starship's development. Human rated in time for the third mission? Getting semi expendable ones (2-3 uses) delivering Starlink v2's within 18mths I can believe. But human rated within 2yrs?

When the Starlink 2.0 launching program starts thousands of satellites will have laser capabilities, and since they are building them with Starship comm. in mind I suspect at least some of those satellites will have dedicated lasers for Deep Space operations. If that's true 4K streaming won't be a problem.
ESA has been doing this since 2016, with a couple of Ka band relay satellites in GEO to serve LEO clients via laser, and I have to say 1 Gbit/s is a pretty nifty link.
What about Orion for Artemis you say?
It will still fly with Apollo era S band radio, "delivering" a whopping 2 Mbit/s, slower than most ADSLs. Not even 480p video will go through that.
And even if they plan to use optical technologies in future missions it will still be limited by the atmosphere since they will be using stations on earth 🤦🏻‍♂️
Maybe the second mission will be what Tim said, rendezvous and dock to Starship in orbit.

Q:It's all starship or you will dock with a Dragon for launch and landing?
A:No but it's a great idea.
Q:Polar orbit?
A:No but it's a great idea.

*concern*
Self proclaimed "astronaut"...

I don’t think you should be going along with the “all-civilian orbital mission” thing - after all, NASA’s whole deal is that they’re a civilian agency. “All-private” or “all non-career astronauts” would be a more accurate description.

At 5:40, the last remark and smile on Jared is pretty suspicious. Time will tell but it seems the 2nd mission would involve ascent in Dragon and docking with a starship in orbit and re-entry back in the Dragon. This would be a huge milestone and proof of concept for Artemis as well since HLS is not designed to take astronauts on orbit itself but instead, I believe it involves a transfer from Orion to Starship in orbit.

Given that they made it sound like Inspiration4's orbit was already pushing the margins, I wonder how Polaris is going to get into (and out of) such a high orbit. Will it be carrying extra fuel somewhere, or does the F9/Dragon stack have more delta-V for this than has been previously let on?
(I know Gemini needed to use the Agena to boost its orbit so high.)

Hey, a question: why doesn't SpaceX split the Starship into Tanks and Payload/Crew for landing and lands the tanks and such like they want now but return the crew and payload by parachutes? yes, it would mean that they lose a bit of payload capacity for Starship but at least the crew would be safe at any time and wouldn't have to endure the high g-loads with the belly flip and the touch down burn and they would be in way less of a risk since the probability that the raptors have a problem or something is way smaller than the parachutes failing since its way more difficult to start an engine then to deploy parachutes. Fusion is expensive, but 3d printing a tinny reactor before we have ignition will get us there faster.  Getting a very small amount of Helium Three He3 from the moon without mining it will give us the material to do it.  One approach is to get Hydro gel/hydrophilic form that attract water and just drop it on the moon so it will fill with water and helium from the intermittent atmosphere caused by the sun.  Pick it back up a few years later with the fuel we need.  We could 3d print the reactors about 30 cm by melting and ink jetting the superconductor ceramic in the sintered metal powder layer.  It would allow complex plumbing for cooling and liquid nitrogen, and even boron chambers for deuterium/tritium reaction.  However, Helium Three He3 will produce protons be safe to be around not damage the superconductor coils, and allow us to test plasma in radical Stellarator like designs in an open classroom.  Cost thousands of dollars instead of billions to iterate the designs and get us to fusion faster.  So, we have used hydro gel to pull particles from space before why not use it on the moon to pull He3 without mining it.
